stem: A child is diagnosed with Kawasaki Disease and is prescribed high-dose aspirin and IVIG. The parents ask why the child needs aspirin given the risk of Reye Syndrome. What is the nurse's best response?

options.text: IVIG eliminates the risk of Reye Syndrome in these patients.
The child will only receive one dose to avoid any toxic effects.
Aspirin is the only medication that can lower the high-grade fever.
It is used to prevent coronary artery aneurysms and blood clots.

rationale.correct: Kawasaki Disease is an exception to the 'no aspirin for children' rule. It is used for its anti-inflammatory and anti-platelet effects to prevent coronary artery aneurysms.
rationale.incorrect: Tylenol/Ibuprofen can lower fever. IVIG does not stop Reye risk; only avoiding viral exposure during therapy helps. Aspirin is continued for weeks (low dose) after the initial high-dose phase.

answerBreakdown.label: A
answerBreakdown.content: In this specific NGN scenario, "IVIG eliminates the risk of Reye Syndrome in these patients." is incorrect as it introduces clinical risk or deviates from standard triage logic.

answerBreakdown.label: B
answerBreakdown.content: Choosing "The child will only receive one dose to avoid any toxic effects." represents a misinterpretation of the gathered cues or a failure to prioritize physiological needs.

answerBreakdown.label: C
answerBreakdown.content: While plausible in other contexts, "Aspirin is the only medication that can lower the high-grade fever." is not the highest priority or most relevant factor in this acute scenario.

answerBreakdown.label: D
answerBreakdown.content: Selecting "It is used to prevent coronary artery aneurysms and blood clots." is evidence-based as it directly correlates with the primary clinical cues and pathophysiology.

clinicalPearls: Kawasaki is the leading cause of acquired heart disease in children.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember Kawasaki is the ONLY major pediatric NCLEX topic where Aspirin is indicated and prioritized.

mnemonic.title: C-R-A-S-H
mnemonic.expansion: Conjunctivitis, Rash, Adenopathy, Strawberry tongue, Hands/feet swelling.
